dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE establishing the race track, Ruidoso Downs (pronounced Ree-oh-do-so), set among the beautiful mounta of New Mexico's Lincoln National Forest, as a white Chrys turns in with a stream of cars moving toward the parking area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE through the open driver-side window of the Chrys at LILLY DILLON, 39 but looking younger, beautiful but co and watchful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT, track in b.g. as Lilly parks the Chrysler, get out, locks the car. As she walks toward the track, WIPE RIGHT, as SCENE TWO WIPES IN from the left. SCENE ONE CAM FOLLOWS Lilly as she walks across the large parking area. SPLIT SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downtown Los Angeles, near the courts and the business section. ROY DILLON, 25, handsome and charming but self indulgent, parks his orange Honda convertible, gets out, picks up a large ledger book from the back seat, goes aro to open the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on the trunk, establishing the tools of the salesman's trade: catalogs, samples, ledgers full of manu and product sheets. Roy adds the ledger from the back sea shuts the trunk, walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy walks around the corner near a bar/restaurant. As he approaches it, WIPE LEFT, the two half-width scenes contracting to one-third each as SCENE THREE WIPES IN fro the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCENE ONE: Lilly approaches the track's entrance doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCENE TWO: Roy approaches the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A baby blue Cadillac parks in front of a jeweler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on the driver's door as MYRA LANGTRY, 36, beauti in an impersonal calculating way, gets out, carrying a sm jewelry care, and locks the car. At first glance, Myra lo rather like Lilly. (Myra always wears large dangly earrin and usually wears big-lensed dark sunglasses.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCENE ONE: Lilly enters the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCENE TWO: Roy enters the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCENE THREE: Myra enters the jeweler's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIPE RIGHT AND LEFT, as SCENE TWO takes FULL SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on a hurried bartender in a full bar, crowded wi NOISY lunchtime crowd. In b.g., Roy slithers his way to t bar, waving a bill in the air to attract the bartender's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Roy as the bartender comes to him. Roy puts t bill on the bar, holding it down with one finger, as he SHOUTS his order. The bartender looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARTENDER'S POV: Roy's finger holds down a twenty dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE steep over Roy's shoulder, the twenty visible, a the bartender hurries away to get the drink. Roy's hand m a fist, swallowing the twenty, opens, pushing a ten out o the bar, holding it there with one finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on the bartender returning with a draft beer, nodding to other ORDERS shouted to him along the way, put the beer down, grabbing the bill without looking at it, hurrying away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Roy, content, smiling, sipping his beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on the bartender, hurrying by, slapping Roy's ch down, moving on, Roy nodding acknowledgement, reaching ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, the change, a ten dollar bill on top. Roy's hand clos over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT, the tote board at the track, showing the shift odds on the horses for the next race, the amounts bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT, number 3. Not much bet, odds 70-1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Lilly, frowning at the tote board. She carrie large heavy shoulder-bag, which she opens, looking in it though it were a file drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Lilly studying the contents of her bag, the t beyond her, the mountains visible out beyond the track wa Lilly moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on a high-dollar betting window, as Lilly approaches, taking bank-banded wads of bills from her bag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A change of numbers sweeps across the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly moves away from the betting window, tucking betting tickets into her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU, Lilly's bag, compartmented, with stacks of money, sm envelopes and notes on notepaper in each compartment. Lil carefully files the betting slips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Lilly looking out at the tote board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, number 3. Odds 32-1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Lilly, not satisfied. She turns and goes back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE at the betting window as Lilly arrives and makes more bets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, number 3. Odds 32-1. CROWD NOISE INCREASES. The numbe shift: odds 26-1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they're off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very quiet, stately; abrupt contrast with the track. A sl ticking clock. Myra sits in the client's chair, while at the desk sits t JEWELER, a pleasant but overweight man of 40, who studies jeweled bracelet through a loupe. He sighs, drops the lou shakes his head regretfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Langtry, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (personal emotion mixed in) You are a valued customer, as you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't understand a thing like this. It's something you almost never see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up bracelet) This is some of the finest filigreed platinum I've ever seen. But the stones, no. They're not diamonds, Mrs. Langtry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they must be! They cut glass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wry) Glass will cut glass, Mrs. Langtry. Do you know where it was purchased?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An expensive hotel room, with a sunstruck day beyond the windows. Myra, naked, a few years younger, sits cross-leg on the bed and laughs at COLE "FARMER" LANGLEY, 55, strin bodied, who stands naked, his back to us, hands on hips, presenting himself to Myra. She reaches forward, hand hid by his body as she lifts something that was hanging on something at the front of him. She brings back the bracel looks at it, is delighted, puts it on, and then leans for again toward the unmoving Cole, her head hidden by his bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a gift. It isn't worth anything at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warm, encouraging) Why, of course it is. I can offer you -- well, five hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra expected -- and needed -- a lot more. She's worried, tense, but stuck. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) I'll get you a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves the room. Myra grimaces, in almost physical pai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another crowded lunchtime bar. A big beefy BARTENDER move quickly, carrying a draft beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Roy, in position, finger holding bill down, a the bartender arrives, puts down the beer, reaches for th bill, stops, stares at the bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT, the bartender and Roy, as the bartender gives R very cold look. He knows, and Roy knows he knows. Roy tri an innocent smile, which doesn't work. Roy moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, the ten dollar bill, as Roy grabs it, but the bartend simultaneously grabs Roy's wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Roy and the bartender as Roy tries to pull aw and the bartender holds him with his left hand while reac under the bar with his right. He comes up with a sawed-of baseball bat. Roy, seeing it, throws his free arm up to protect his head, but the bartender pushes the blunt end the bat straight across the bar at a downward angle and h into Roy's solar plexus, driving the air out of him and propelling him back away from the bar, leaving the ten. T nearest CUSTOMERS on both sides become aware that somethi happened, but nothing follows and they're already involve conversations. The bartender scoops up the ten as he puts bat away under the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Roy, arms folded across his torso, staring in shock toward the bar, where the space he filled has alrea been closed in by other bodies. Nearly retching, he stumb toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on four PEOPLE at a table, CHEERING a race, switching to disgust and despair when they lose, moving a from the table, leaving their betting tickets behind. Lil passes by, smoothly and casually scoops up the tickets, m on along a row of tables, and there finding more tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra sits as before. The jeweler enters with a check, whi he hands her. She looks up at him, making no move to leav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're not too badly disappointed with us, Mrs. Langtry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not your fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll give us an opportunity to serve you again, I hope. If there's anything you think we might be interested in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have only one thing now. Are you interested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd have to see it, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are seeing it. You're looking right at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jeweler is puzzled, then startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away, goes behind his desk, sits down, looks at Myra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something, Mrs. Langtry? A bracelet like that very rarely happens. A fine setting and workmanship usually mean precious stones. It always hurts me when I find they're not. I always hope --  (faint sad friendly smile) -- I'm mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra likes him better now, even though he hasn't solved h problem. She rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. For everything you felt you could do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy has been throwing up but is finished now. He's sprawl like a shot deer across the hood of his Honda, still clutching his stomach. A police car stops, the passenger gets out. He's suspicious at first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? Everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sight of the uniform forces Roy into gear. He straightens, smiling through his pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting better. A bad shrimp, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The con's suspicion changes to concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want us to take you to a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no, I'm fine now, thanks, anyway. Still got a lot of clients to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late afternoon. AN ANGLE on the parking area, where almos all the cars are gone and the few remaining are widely separated. The white Chrysler is one of these. Lilly walk it from the track entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on the Chrysler as Lilly opens the trunk, puts h bag inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP, Lilly and the trunk. She takes betting tickets her bag, sorts them, files them in envelopes in different compartments, puts some to one side, then sorts through t separated tickets, throwing some away, keeping some. She takes money from the bag, puts tickets in, closes the bag with the money on the trunk floor. Reaching farther in, s lifts the pad deep inside the trunk, lifts the metal floo panel, and reveals a cache mostly filled with money. She today's skim, puts everything away, puts the bag back on shoulder, closes the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shabby apartment hotel on Wilshire. An exterior hall balcony on each floor has the entrance doors to the front apartments. Roy's Honda makes the turn and enters the basement garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Modest but clean. The owner, SIMMS, a sloppy garrulous ol bore, talks with a potential RENTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it this way, now. Say I rent to a woman, well, she has to have a room with a bath. I insist on it, because otherwise she's got the hall bath tied up all the time, washing her goddamn hair and her clothes and everything she can think of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In b.g., Roy, still in pain, comes out of the elevator, w to Simms, who waves back without pausing in his monologue and crosses to the mailboxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, your minimum for a room with bath is three hundred a month, just for a place to sleep and no cooking allowed. And just how many of these tootsies make that kind of money and have to eat in restaurants and buy clothes and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, carrying his junk mail and pretending not to be in p crosses to Simms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Simms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fawning) Why yes, Mr. Dillon. Here's a potential new neighbor, looking at--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uninterested) Uh-huh. Mrs. Langtry may drop by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simms doesn't like Mrs. Langtry, but can't say so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll send her right up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy goes back to the elevator. Simms continues his monolo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had my first hotel thirty-seven years ago in Wichita Falls, Texas, and that's where I began to learn about women. They just don't make the money, you see, not regular they don't, and there's only one way they can get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy enters the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, that Mr. Dillon there, that's the fine type of person I have in mind for here. Like yourself, I have no doubt. He's a salesman, regular as clockwork, has a suite here. Fine man. Now, about these women. At first, you know, they just go out and do it now and then, just enough to make ends meet. But pretty soon they got that bank open twenty-four hours a day, and then you've got trouble. Hookers and hotellin' just don't mix. You'd think the cops'd be too busy catching real criminals, not snooping around after working girls, but that's the way the gravy stains, as the saying is, and I don't fight it. An ounce of prevention is my motto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra enters from the front, looks across at Simms, points upward. Simms calls to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, Mrs. Langtry, he's up there, he's expecting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra crosses to the elevator. Simms speaks more softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you keep out the women in the first place, see, you keep out the hookers, and then you keep out the cops, and that's how you have a clean place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE along the balcony, with Roy's apartment door in and Los Angeles in b.g. Myra crosses to the door, opens i with her key, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small crowded old-fashioned bathroom. Roy, shirt open a trousers pushed down almost to his crotch, looks in the mirror at purplish greenish bruises on his stomach. He touches his stomach, winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the door, then grins at his reflection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your medicine is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hotel furniture, shabby and anonymous. On the walls, contrasting with everything else, are two crying-clown pictures on black velvet, mounted in big boxy frames. Myr stands in the middle of the room, and Roy enters, shirt a trousers still disarranged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused by clothing) Well, well. In a real hurry, are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always, for you, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for her, but she playfully holds him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You aren't taking me for granted, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking you for granite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grins, as his fingertip prods her breast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That isn't granite. If that fell on me, it wouldn't hurt at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing along) Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling her close) Let's find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly's white Chrysler is parked next to an open-air phon Traffic whizzes by. Lilly talks on the phone, with pen an notebook at the ready. The racetrack is visible in the b.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm done here. Do I come back to Baltimore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be an expensive, if gaudy, lawyer's office. Baltimore harbor is visible past the windows. IRV, the accountant, sits at a desk covered -- but neatly covered with ledgers, computer printouts, etc. He speaks on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo wants you to go on to Delmar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delmar? I never go out to California. That's a thousand miles from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine hundred. Bobo needs somebody to handle playback this time. Come on, Lilly, you don't argue with Bobo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fatalistic) I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take two, three days. Call when you get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll swing around Los Ang gleez on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Lilly making the best of the situation. She liste bit more, GRUNTS a farewell, hangs up, moves to her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, anonymous hotel furniture. Roy and Myra naked in b he on his back, she straddling him, both moving gently. H half feeling pleasure, half unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I am, baby, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy? It this all we have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All? It ain't bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more than this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to concentrate on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking abut, Myra? Marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. You aren't marriage material.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps watching her, ironic, hips moving. Looking for a distraction, she notices the bruise on his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches it; he flinches back, in real pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! Hey, what are you trying to do, throw me off my game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) No, baby. Come to Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She folds forward onto him. He puts his arms around her. rock together slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same mountains in b.g. as at the track. Lilly carries small bags from her motel room, puts them on the back sea the Cadillac, gets behind the wheel, drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra, dressed, primps at the mirror, surveys herself critically, is reasonably satisfied, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy lies supine on the bed, semi-conscious, half-covered sheet. Myra, casual, not noticing his condition, leans he head in through the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wore you out, did I? It's a good woman you can't keep down, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves fitfully, CROAKS an attempt at speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a good sleep, baby. Call you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits up, trying to grin and be easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait'll next year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE across Roy's profile, with open bedroom door bey him. Through it, the living room and outer door can be se Myra crosses the living room, opens the door. Bright sunl pours in, emphasizing the sweat on his face. She closes t door, and he gives up trying to smile. Gingerly, he touch his bruised stomach, winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn that guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to get out of bed, but movement creates pain. sits back against the headboard, looks around, reaches painfully to the bedside table drawer, takes a quarter fr it, studies the quarter, feels it with fingertips, places on the back of his left hand, slowly moves the soft pads his right palm over it, then turns the quarter over and repeats. Then he takes the quarter in his right hand, fli it, slaps it down onto the back of his left hand, SPEAKS simultaneously with the hands coming together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks away, right hand moving minimally on left hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts the right hand, nods, then flips the coin again, looks away, moves the right hand slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again he's right. Again he repeats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's about to repeat when a wave of weakness comes over h He sits back, gasping, but won't acknowledge the problem. He forces himself to flip the coin, misses catching it, f it on the blanket, flips it again, slaps it onto the back the other hand, looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right again. He prepares to flip the coin, but then his h sags onto the covers, his chin drops, his eyes glaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispered) How much can I bet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train runs through a forest, tree shadows making a li and-dark pattern. Roy, four or five years younger, sits w a three-core-monte gang, consisting of a DEALER, a specta SHILL beside him, Roy facing the dealer, a ROPER next to On a briefcase on the dealer's lap are three cards, face An ace and two deuces. Across the aisle, alone in the sea sits MINTZ, a conman in his fifties, pretending not to wa but watching with amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's between you two. I got nothing at stake here, I'm just dealing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we both guess wrong? You aren't gonna take...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dealer turns aside, allowing himself to be distracted and the shill ARGUE nonsensically. The roper nudges Roy, reaches out and crimps the ace. Roy's doing a wide-eyed bumpkin kid; he stares at the roper in delight and amazem

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on the shill, arguing with the dealer but lookin toward Roy and the roper, then increasing the force of hi argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE across the amused Mintz at the roper whispering Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT, Roy and the roper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got him now! Put down that big bill you got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispered) The fifty or the hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hundred! Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtful) The ace is what I want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roper's having trouble keeping his patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT, the dealer and the shill, fake-squabbling, Roy the roper seen in b.g. between their faces, Roy finally bringing out his wallet, withdrawing a bill. Relieved, th dealer and the shill cut the crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on the group as Roy puts his hundred dollar bill the briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shill pulls a messy wad of bills from his inner pocke uses most of it to cover the bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're damn right that's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picks up the cards) Whoever finds the ace, wins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU, the dealer's hands, shuffling the cards at lightning speed. He deals the cards out face down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, Roy's sweat-covered face, eyelids fluttering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispered) Dark in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on the group. Roy squints at the cards, light an dark playing on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too dark. I just can't see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casually, but too quickly to be stopped, he reaches acros and plucks the shill's glasses off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me borrow these, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE across Mintz, surprised and amused, at the group b.g., in consternation as Roy puts on the glasses and loo down at the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, that's better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROY'S POV: The glasses are 'readers.' Through them, a lar gray 'A' can be seen on the back of one of the non-crimpe cards. Roy's hand reaches out and flips it over. It's the of spades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE across Roy toward the doorway. Roy, eyes closed, smiles in triumph, then winces in pain. Mintz partially appears, hovering beside the bed, grinning at Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't teach you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispered) You taught me a lot. Then I invented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weary bored people sit around waiting. Roy, 17, lugging a suitcase, walks through, takes a seat near Mintz, who's d card tricks for his own pleasure. Roy watches, then moves closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see how you did that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scram. Go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I just left home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too young. You should be in school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am in school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mintz peers at him, taking an interest. Then he holds up five of spades, shows it to Roy, puts it back in the deck shuffles, shows Roy the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the five?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your other hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mintz grins slowly, turns his hand over with the palmed c showing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy slumps, eyes closed, half-smiling, with the fever Min hovering. Roy's smile fades, his fluttering eyelids grow still, his face slack. The fever Mintz fades and disappea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on a large sign indicating "Los Angeles" straigh ahead. CAMERA PANS DOWN and around 180 degrees to face th several lanes of heavy Los Angeles-bound traffic. LONG BE Hundreds of cars rush by. CAMERA PANS with Lilly's white Chrysler as it comes along in the stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE through the Chrysler's left side window at Lilly driving, concentrating, biting her left thumbnail. She becomes aware that's what she's doing, shakes her head in irritation: She's trying to break herself of this habit. Ostentatiously she tucks the thumb into her fist, rests t fist on top of the steering wheel, where she can keep an on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH ANGLE on the westbound lanes. The Chrysler passes. S it's out of sight among all the other cars. LONG BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE across the unmoving unconscious Roy toward the doorway. The apartment door beyond the living room opens, throwing light on Roy, who doesn't react. Lilly enters, i silhouette, closes the door, crosses toward the bedroom. (Until she speaks, we can't be quite sure who this is. Wi the similarity between herself and Myra, this could be My

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitant) Roy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reaction. Lilly, getting worried, moves closer, throug the bedroom doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy? You asleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His head moves slightly. He barely has strength to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves forward to the side of the bed, only her torso FRAME. She touches a hand to his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) My God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns, hurries back to the living room, looks around the phone, crosses to it, dials, SPEAKS. Roy's eyes open, frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly, hard and fast and urgent, on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the doctor I work for Bobo Justus, and this is an emergency. Don't worry, he knows who Bobo is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE down toward Roy, from above, he's weak but troub Eyes closed, frowning, whispering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away, Lilly. Go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's eyes close. He looks dead. SLOW FADE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR, a nervous heavyset man in his fifties, a drin from the look of him, is on the phone in b.g., while Lill prowls the room, looking at everything with distaste, the stopping to frown at the box-framed clown pictures. She doesn't get it. She touches one of the pictures, trying t understand. The doctor hangs up, turns to Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lugubrious) The ambulance is on the way, for what good it will do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? He's going to be all right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dillon, your son was in some sort of accident. He's had an internal hemorrhage, he's bleeding to death inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, make it stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His blood pressure is under a hundred. I don't think he'll live to get to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icy, stern) You know who I work for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's uncomfortable, wants to dismiss that part of his lif

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, but that's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son will be all right. If he isn't, I'll have you killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor stares at her in astonishment, then in belief. SOUND of ambulance siren. To break the moment, he crosses the door, opens it. Light bathes Lilly. The doctor steps across the threshold, waiting for the ambulance. He looks back at Lilly, who stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU, Roy, skin pallid, eyes closed and sunken, lips white SOUND of siren LOUDER. SOUND SEGUES to CHILD CRYING. CRYI FADES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clumsy slum hotel fifteen years ago, with a tiny lobby, DESK CLERK at a half-door in one wall. Lilly, at 24, ente from the street. This is a definite hooker, with bright maroon hair and a black-and-white miniskirt. She stops wordlessly at the desk for her key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing key) Your kid's in the back here. He's crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy? He's always crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sympathetic to Roy) The kids beat him up, because his home life is, uh, different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ironic) I like you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk shrugs. He doesn't like this tough broad. He tu and calls back into his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, your mother's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, 10, comes reluctantly out to Lilly, sniffling and rubbing his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's your story today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They twisted my arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing lightly) Only one arm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries not to cry, and shows her a space between his te

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They knocked out my tooth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only one tooth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's frustrated, unhappy, having nowhere else to turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always say that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly won't take him seriously, but she relents enough to stop teasing him, and to pat his head, ignoring how he flinches away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, kid, let's see if there's any food in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (there's no food) Hah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly gives him a jaundiced look, walks Roy to the stairs up. The clerk, scornful but sexually interested, watches go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU, Roy in a hospital bed, with more color in his face, breathing more normally. He begins to react to the sound people speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really, you're Roy's mother? That's impossible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite. But I'm not sure who you are, Mrs... Langtry, was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's eyes open, he looks toward the voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Roy's friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT, Lilly and Myra facing one another across the f of Roy's bed, in a two-bed hospital room. (The OLD MAN in other bed sleeps through the scene.) Neither woman is yet aware that Roy's awake. Lilly looks Myra up and down, wit obvious contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I imagine you're lots of people's friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra moves one pace to the side, studying Lilly's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, of course, now that I see you in the light, you're plenty old enough to be Roy's mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweet smile) Aren't we all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very weak, but amused) Play nice. Don't fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women, startled, both move toward Roy, one on each si of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE SHOT, Myra and Lilly both leaning over to look down Roy's sleepy face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy. You're going to be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I am. What made you turn up, after all these years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm working down in San Diego. Just for a few weeks. (awkward laugh) Thought I'd drop in on my long-lost son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold) Nice to see you. (turns to Myra) What am I doing in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were bleeding inside, honey. Remember that bruise you had?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called the doctor, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctant) Well, no, Roy. Your mother found you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tossing It away) Oh, yeah? (very casual, to Lilly) Thanks. (back to Myra) How long do they say I'm in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra's willing to fight with Lilly, but Roy's attitude to his mother makes her uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy... Your mom saved your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy turns his head, gives Lilly an ironic smile. Lilly wa holding herself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Only one life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, accepting that, but then responds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second time I gave it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy gives her a cold smile, then turns to Myra for the ir explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was kind of... inconvenient... for Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly has nothing but contempt for Myra. To be humiliated front of Myra -- and by her son -- is the worst thing tha could happen to her. She makes as dignified an exit as sh can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... You're all right now, I guess. I have to get down to the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctant, but it's necessary) Thanks, uh, Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkward laugh) Don't mention it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I owe you my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faint smile) You always did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly exits. Myra looks after her, curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Down to the track?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy will not talk about this, with anyone. His response i cold, closing the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bright smile) I want to know everything about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easy grin) You do. And once I'm out of here, I'll remind you of the best parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile flirtatiously at one another, both with their minds on other things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very messy, small. Myra showers. She finishes, emerges, w herself in a towel, opens the crowded messy medicine cabi removes cosmetics and other items, starts to tweeze her eyebrows. Doorbell RINGS. She looks irritated, ignores it Long doorbell RING. Exasperated, she slaps the tweezers d exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another furnished apartment, this one with Myra's clothin and dishes and glasses and other junk all over it. She crosses to the door, pulls it open. The APARTMENT MAN enters; a sullen, nervous, heavyset man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry, but defensive) You heard the shower, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about that. This time, I gotta have the rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra forces herself to be more pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, I thought I was gonna be all  right by now, I just need a little more --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't the owner, Myra, it's my wife. She knows what's going on. This time, I gotta have the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, you know you'll --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In gesturing, Myra "accidentally" loses the towel, then w it around herself again as the manager stares nervously a She smiles, knowing she's got him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, could we talk it over? Do you want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife sent me here, Myra. For the money. She's waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have it tonight. Nine o'clock? Ten?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be determined) This time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll work something out, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She strokes his arm, smiling. He flees. She smiles till h gone, then looks worried, leans her head against the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, very comfortable in pajamas and robe, sits in a wheelchair beside the bed, with magazines lying handy on bed. Myra, irritable, paces beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see why you're still here. You look healthy to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just do what the doctor says, babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just comfortable, that's all. You don't even ask to go home. You just lie around, let your mama take care of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (truly astonished) Mama!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else is paying for all this? You badmouth the woman all the time, but you sure do take the payoffs she gives you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insulted) I'll pay Lilly back, don't you worry about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like to come here, Roy. Every time I do, your mother comes in and makes remarks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just Lilly's way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you never defend me. You're afraid of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't be stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a mama's boy, if you want the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so absurd, Roy doesn't know how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kid --? I hadn't even seen her in seven years!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly enters, smiling in self-confidence. A large ugly bu is on the back of her right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should my ears be burning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surly) They might as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly gives her a mock-admiring look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard those skirts were coming back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra's not quite up to direct confrontation with Lilly. S glowers at Roy instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get well soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easy) Every day in every way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you when you get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra stalks out. Acting as though Myra hadn't existed, Li puts her bag on the bed, takes mail from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually dismissive) Just a little accident. I went by your place, picked up your mall. Just bills, I'll take care of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take care of my own bills, Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indifferent shrug) Whatever you say. The manager says your boss called. (crooked grin) Really pulled the wool over everybody's eyes, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? So I've got a job. So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop kidding me! Four years in a town like Los Ang-gleez, and a peanut selling job is the best you can do? You expect me to believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spreads hands; it's obvious) It's there. The boss called, you said so yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that dump you live in! Those clown pictures on the walls!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This reference alerts and worries Roy, which he tries to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do not! Roy Dillon? Cornball clown pictures? Commission salesman? It's all a front, isn't it? You're on the grift, I know you are. You're working some angle, and don't tell me you're not because I wrote the book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive) You're one to talk. Still running playback money for the mob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me. That's who I am. You were never cut out for the rackets, Roy, and if you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She considers him. His expression is jaunty, daring her. gives him a somber answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You aren't tough enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's afraid she's right. He covers the doubt with a displ of self-assurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as tough as you, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dead serious) No. And you have to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds up her burned hand, showing it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked me about this. You really want to know what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He isn't sure he does; but what choice does he have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boss is a guy named Bobo Justus, back in Baltimore. When a long shot gets too much action, I have to put money on that horse at the track, because it's the only way to get the odds down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first day of the Delmar meet, there was a nag called Bluebell. I should have been on it. But that was the day after you came in here, so I stuck around to see how you were gonna be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would speak protest, deny, explain, but she cuts him o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was my choice, nothing to do with you. I took a chance, and it didn't work out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bluebell came in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sent Bobo ten grand of my own money, like it was the winnings from my bets. I hoped that would cover me. (shrug) It didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on the exit doors toward the parking lot. Lilly comes out, self-absorbed, then sees something ahead of he falters briefly, keeps walking, tries a very shaky smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE ANGLE, as Lilly approaches her car. BOBO JUSTUS, a blunt hoodlum in a good suit and a civilized veneer, st leaning against the car, arms folded, squinting behind sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Bobo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I buy you that dress, you piece of shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly's scared, startled, but trying to figure out how to play this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess so. You're the guy I work for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You work for me, huh? Then I just may flush you down the toilet. Drive me to the Durando.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo gets into the passenger seat, while Lilly nods convulsive agreement and hurries around to get behind the wheel. The car jolts forward, then smooths, and heads for gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving along the highway. Lilly concentrates on traffic. Bobo heavily watches her profile, finally speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bluebell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly's eyes briefly close, her shoulders sag. Then she g back to the silent alert person she'd been. Bobo nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you figure you were gonna get away with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not getting away with anything, Bobo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fuckin right you're not. How much did your pals cut you in for on that nag, huh? Or did they give you the same kind of screwing you gave me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was down on that horse, Bobo. Not as much as I should have been, but there was a lot of action on those--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo taps a fingertip against the side of her head to shu her up. She shuts up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One question. Do you want to stick to that story, or do you want to keep your teeth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to keep my teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'll ask you another. You think I got no contacts out here? That nag paid off at just the opening price. There wasn't hardly a flutter on the tote board from the time the odds were posted. There ain't enough action to tickle the tote, but you claim a ten grand win! You send me ten thousand dollars, like I'm some mark you can blow off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified, broken) Bobo, no, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna talk to me straight up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son was in the hospital --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doin with a son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left home a long time ago. He was in the hospital, up in Los Ang gleez, real sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (utter scorn) Motherhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never fucked up before, Bobo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect me to buy this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time for Lilly to show tough, and she knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do buy it, Bobo. I cost you, and I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo thinks this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a lot of people work for me, Lilly. I can't have shit like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (begging) It'll never happen again. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happened once. With me, that's making a habit of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly drops back to her final position; fatalism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're calling the shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got any kind of long coat in the car? Anything you can wear home over your clothes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadened with fear) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't matter) I'll loan you a raincoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly drives, holding herself together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall expensive hotel on the coast north of San Diego. CAMERA PANS with the Chrysler pulling in and stopping at entrance, then PANS UP the balconied facade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living room of a high-floor suite. CAMERA FACES across th room to the balcony and the view of the ocean. Entrance d to one side. A supermarket shopping bag is on the coffee table. Two THUGS sit on the sofa, watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Lilly enters, followed by Bobo. The th immediately rise and switch off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the thugs) Take a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thugs leave the room as Lilly crosses to stand betwee and the view, followed by Bobo, neither looking out. Lill turns to Bobo, who abruptly punches her hard in the stoma She falls to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE as Bobo steps across her and goes over to c the drapes over the view. Lilly sits up, watching him, waiting obediently. Bobo looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me a bath towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up, hurting, and hurries to the bathroom. Bobo s on the sofa, crosses his ankles on the coffee table next the supermarket bag. He takes out and lights a cigar. Lil comes back with a large white bath towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever hear about the oranges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, the insurance frammis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about the oranges, Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kicks over the supermarket bag. Oranges roll on the fl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While you put those in the towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly's very scared. She drops to her knees, spreads the towel, crawls around gathering oranges while she talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hit a person with the oranges in the towel, they get big, awful looking bruises, but they don't really get hurt, not if you do it right. It's for working scams against insurance companies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you do it wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can louse up your insides. You can get puh, puh, puh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) What's that, Lilly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly pauses, bent over, tightly holding an orange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Permanent damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never shit right again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets to his feet, leaving his cigar in an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard, impatient) Bring me the towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fumbling slightly, she folds the towel edges together to a bag, then stands, brings the towel to Bobo. He makes a production out of getting his grip on the edges just righ She stands as limp as she can, just wanting to get throug this. He looks at her without expression, rears back with towel, swings it forward, lets it drop open. Oranges roll the floor. Lilly stares, wide-eyed, recognizing reprieve. Bobo tosses the towel behind him onto the sofa, then gest contemptuously for her to pick up the oranges again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT, closer, as Lilly turns, bending toward the oran and Bobo picks up his cigar, then lifts a foot and kicks flatfooted, hard, in the back. She sprawls on the floor. follows and drops to his knees on her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE close on Lilly on the floor, Bobo's knees grindi back and forth into her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Bobo, grimacing as he bears down, pressing hi weight onto her back. He leans forward, left hand bracing himself on the floor beside her head as he reaches down w the cigar held in his right hand and presses the ember against the back of her splayed-out right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU, Lilly, clenching her teeth, tears squeezing from her eyes, simply bearing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Bobo, catching a bad smell, looking back down behind himself at Lilly's body. This is the result he wan but it disgusts him. He straightens up, still kneeling on her, puts the cigar in his mouth, doesn't like its taste, removes it, braces his left hand against her back while h lifts off her, getting back up onto his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT, Bobo stepping over her, expression repulsed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go clean yourself up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the cigar back in the ashtray as she rises, cradl her burnt hand. Not looking toward Bobo, hobbling with kn together, she starts from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The raincoat's on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves. He opens the drapes, then picks up an orange the floor and steps out onto the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo stands looking out at the ocean. He enjoys breathing sea air. He slowly peels the orange, dropping pieces of p over the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly appears in the doorway, wearing a too-large man's raincoat. Bobo doesn't seem to notice her at first, then to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost forgot. That ten grand of yours. It's in the envelope by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tries for animation) Oh, thanks, Bobo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, I better not, if it's okay. I still gotta drive back up to Los Ang-gleez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See your son, huh? Well, that's nice. A side of you I didn't know, Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly chances taking a step out onto the balcony. It's vi that she encourage this forgive-and-forget dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good kid. A salesman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the square, huh? And how are you making out these days? Stealing much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo's being jolly now. Lilly's scared, but has to be jol too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From you? My folks didn't raise any stupid kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo's joshing now. He raises a humorous eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not skimming a thing, Lilly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, you know. I just clip a buck here and a buck there. Not enough to notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (honest approval) That's right. Take a little, leave a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A person that don't look out for himself is too dumb to look out for anybody else. He's a liability, right, Bobo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (this is his creed) You're a thousand percent right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or else he's working an angle. If he doesn't steal a little, he's steeling big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it, Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I like that suit, Bobo. I don't know what there is about it, but it somehow makes you look taller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted) Yeah? You really think so? A lot of people been telling me the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can tell them I said they're right. (looks at sky) I better get going. Roy'll wonder where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Worries about his mother, eh? Give him a hug for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. So long, Bobo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly leaves the balcony. Bobo eats more orange, looking at the ocean. His expression is stern but calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly drives along the highway, weeping, shaking, teeth chattering. Her hands are both high on the wheel, the bac the right hand developing a large red burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky! Lucky! Oh, am I lucky.! Am I lucky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's appalled and embarrassed and ashamed by this story; surface result is, he's mad at Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky? You call that lucky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) He let me live. He let me be his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy in his agitation wheels himself back and forth in the wheelchair, bumping into things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't put up with that! Nobody has to put up with that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do if you're where I am. Where you want to be. How'd you get that punch in the stomach, Roy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes down, sullen, not caring if she believes him or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tripped over a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calm maternal advice) Get off the grift, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faint smile) You don't have the stomach for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at her, hurt and angry. She stares back, unflinching. Angrily, he spins the wheelchair around, his back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now she's hurt. She shrugs, speaks indifferently to his b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just give you your life. What you do with it is up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his back turned) That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates, then stalks out, shutting the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing the door close, Roy spins around in the wheelchai face where she'd been. He starts to get up, pauses midway

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry, Lilly takes a step away from the closed door, then stops, looks uncertainly back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, on his feet now, stands still, indecisive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly shakes her head, turns firmly away, marches down th corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy makes an angry gesture, drops back into the wheelchai spins it around and wheels over to the phone. Quick and angry, he makes a call. SOUND of ring; SOUND of click.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered; little-girl flirtatious) Myra here. Sorry you missed me. Tell me how to reach you and I will, just as soon as I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of answering machine beep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe, I'm gettin out of here, and that's it. Let's take some time out this weekend, go down to LaJolla, hit the beach, have some fun. Forget all this other stuff, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy hangs up, sits in the wheelchair looking determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simms talks with a MAID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your difference between your folded towel and your clean towel is a trip to the laundry. When you're cleaning those bathrooms, what you do, you pick up the towel, you give it a good shake and a good look, and you say to yourself, 'Would I dry myself on this towel?' If the answer's yes, fold it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy comes out of the elevator, crossing toward Simms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if it's wet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Dillon! Welcome back! You look fine, just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mr. Simms, I'm feeling fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shy) I'm glad you're better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simms hands Roy a stack of mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're well liked around here, Mr. Dillon. The entire staff will be pleased to see you're back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's touched and embarrassed by this reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thank you. And thank them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sickness comes to us all, Mister Dillon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true, Mr. Simms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never know when and we never know why. We never know how. The only blessed thing we know is, it'll be at the most inconvenient and unexpected time. Just when you've got tickets to the World Series. And that's the way the permanent waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm back now. I just wanted you to know. Gotta rush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy to see you looking so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy crosses back to the elevator, enters it. Elevator doo closes. Simms looks after him, avuncular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That fellow could be a congressman. (turns to maid) If it's wet, you don't fold it. You shake it, and hang it neatly on the rod provided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. SARBER & WEBB - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long low stucco building in an industrial section of Lo Angeles. The company name is on the glass of the main doo KAGGS, a humorless hotshot of 28, dressed in short-sleeve white shirt and narrow dark tie, prowls the cracked sidew in front of the place, MAKING REMARKS into a small casset recorder. Roy's Honda arrives and drives into the company at the end of the building. Kaggs watches, then goes on patrolling and TALKING into the recorder. Roy comes out t the sidewalk and heads for the entrance. Kaggs stops and watches him approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerful, confident) Whadaya say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uptight, minimal) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy continues on and enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. SARBER & WEBB - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A low rail separates the visitors from an area of desks w CLERKS typing or adding up figures or TALKING on the phon Beyond them are floor-to-ceiling bins and shelves with na aisles between, in which more CLERKS move busily, filling orders or doing inventory. A great sense of activity and hubbub. Roy enters, looks around in surprise. A clerk at front desk sees him, stands happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy! Welcome back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching him) What's going on? This is usually coffee break time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not since Kaggs showed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other clerks, aware of Roy, come over with AD LIB GREETIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily basking) Hey, yeah, I'm fine, everything's great. What's this Kaggs? Sounds like a disease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troubleshooter from the main office. Came out here right after you went into the hospital, and he ain't had a kind word for anybody yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody knows anything but him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chopped off half a dozen salesmen; won't wholesale to them any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of sense does that make? They're all on commission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unworried) You think he'll chop me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he does, he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he comes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerks all hurry back to their desks as Kaggs enters. crosses to Roy, hand stuck out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaggs. Home office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his hand) Roy Dillon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keeping Roy's hand) I know that. Knew it when I saw you out there. The best salesman here, which isn't saying much. Want to talk to you, Dillon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaggs moves toward the gate in the rail, still holding Ro hand, to move him along. Roy stands still, which yanks Ka back. Kaggs frowns at him, releases his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a pretty backhanded compliment. If I let people get away with things like that, I wouldn't be a good salesman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brisk) You're right. I apologize. But I still want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lead on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaggs leads the way through the rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small, crowded, efficient, with interior windows showing aisles of bins. Kaggs leads Roy in, shuts the door, gestu at the second chair as he goes behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both sit, Roy amused and observant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I said you being the best salesman here didn't say much, I meant for us. I know your record with Sarber and Webb, and I'd say you're a top-flight man, but you've had no incentive. No one walking on your heels. Just a lot of half asses, so the tendency's been not to stretch yourself. I'm bouncing the slobs, incidentally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dry) So I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes no difference to me if they're only on commission. If they don't make good money, they're not giving us good representation, and we can't afford to have them around. Ever supervise salesmen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, you've had to supervise yourself. This place needs a sales manager. Somebody who's proved he's a salesman and can handle other salesmen. He'd have a lot of deadwood to clear out, new men to hire. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy doesn't yet know he's being offered the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a good Idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know offhand what your best year's been, we can look it up. The idea is, we'll top it by fifteen percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Roy gets it. He's startled, almost scared, thinks automatically of escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just the first year. If you aren't worth a lot more than that the second year, I'll kick you out. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh... No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astonished) No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't take that job! I mean, I mean, I can't take it right away. I'm still recuperating, I just dropped in to say hello, see everybody --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't realize. Yeah, you do look a little pale. How soon will you be ready? A week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you need a man right now. It wouldn't be fair to you to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take care of the being-fair-to-me department. Things've gone to hell this long, they can go a little longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trapped) Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaggs gets to his feet, terminating the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you in a week, Roy. I can call you Roy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Oh, sure. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaggs sticks his hand out for another shake. Roy obliges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm Perk. Short for Percy, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) Perk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's place. Roy enters from the bedroom, carrying a suitcase, which he drops on the sofa. He goes to one of t box-framed clown pictures, takes it off the wall, puts it face down on the coffee table, removes two wing nuts hold the back, lifts off the back, and reveals stacks of money hidden inside. He takes two wads of money out, counting t putting them on the coffee table, then fits the back in place, reattaches the wing nuts, and hangs the picture on wall. Stuffing the wads of money into the suitcase, he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab pulls up to discharge passengers. Roy and the DRIVE get out. Roy pays the driver, who opens the trunk to take several pieces of luggage. Myra leans hesitantly out, as though afraid it's raining out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This really is it. Union Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra comes out of the cab. She's feeling testy. Roy's in good mood and ignores her bad temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see why we have to take the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra and Roy burden themselves with the luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we want to drive somewhere while we're there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll rent a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start for the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big spender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't seen nothin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE from outside the passenger car through the windo Myra, mulish, watching the scenery go by. Beyond her Roy' easy, content. He moves to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT, within the train. Myra looks questioningly at R as he stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stretch my legs. Come along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not ready to relent and enjoy herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unruffled) See you soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks down the aisle behind Myra, who sighs and looks the window again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four young SOLDIERS sit at a table in a rudimentary bar c They're drinking bloody Marys out of plastic glasses and having a good time together. In b.g., several customers a clustered at the small service bar, waiting for drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Roy, at the service bar, looking back past ot people at the soldiers. He gets his mixed drink, in a pla glass, and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on the soldiers as Roy starts by. The train lurc and Roy falls heavily against their table, slopping their drinks and spilling some of his own on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Ow, I'm sorry! Oh, look, I spilled your drinks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay, pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me buy you a new round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, no, no problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't like spill much at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy firmly places his own glass on their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are those, bloody Marys? Watch this, I'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves, while the soldiers are still PROTESTING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra applies makeup, watching herself in her compact mirr She becomes aware of eyes, and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT, Myra and a BUSINESSMAN, sitting across the way, grinning at her. Myra registers him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, Myra, considering the possibilities. Then she shrugs, shakes her head at the businessman almost reluctantly, an goes back to applying makeup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy now sits with the soldiers, eagerly listening to them talk. There are plastic glasses enough on the table for t rounds of drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Soldier 2) Yeah, but it was you like told the sergeant your grandmother was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Soldier 3) And you jumped right in. (broad imitation) I'll drive him, Sarge, he's too distraught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astonished) Distraught? You said distraught?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh, Roy laughing with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy! You guys could've got in a lot of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. Old Sarge, he's slowing down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I wouldn't take a chance like that. (looks at floor) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch as he bends, picks up one die from the floor, holds it where they can all see it, his manner open, guileless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of you fellows drop this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra walks down the aisle, demurely looking at no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's getting to his feet, the soldiers protesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't buy every round!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like our turn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what. We'll roll for it. Low number buys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the die to Soldier 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. You roll for the four of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers are confused but agreeable, seeing this as s kind of fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
