dialogues.text: Here goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses the die on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a four!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy picks up the die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE close on Roy, his eyes glittering, his fist with die shaking beside his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT. Roy throws. They all look at the die. Roy spre his hands; the good sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told you I'd buy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just doesn't seem fair, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you what. Give me a chance to get even when I come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra reaches the end of one car, starts through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Myra about to enter. She stops, looking throu the glass in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra's POV: Roy and the soldiers rolling the die for mone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU, Myra, absorbed, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra's POV: MOS through the glass. ECU, Roy's hand with t die. ECU, Roy's profile, his smile, his innocent distress when he wins. ECU, Roy's hand scoops money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU, Myra, smiling, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brightly lit Hopperish place. Lilly sits alone in a boo eating a bowl of chili and reading a newspaper folded bes the bowl. A DRUNK with a great deal of faith in his own c sits with a male FRIEND at the counter, drinking coffee. drunk keeps looking toward Lilly, grinning, COMMENTING playfully to his friend, who's bored by it all. Lilly doe seem to be aware of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drunk rises from his stool, turning toward Lilly, staggering slightly. His friend makes a small move to sto him, then shrugs and lets him go. The drunk makes his way Lilly's table, leans on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty woman like you shouldn't eat alone. Whadaya wanna eat alone for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly gives him a flat look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks past him toward the WAITRESS behind the counter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Could I have some coffee, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could have coffee together. My name's Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly looks over at the drunk's friend, who pointedly ign the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your pal wants you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drunk could turn mean; his gesture brushing away the of his friend is stronger than necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him find his own pretty woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress arrives, with the coffee pot and a mug. She the mug on the table, pours coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This fellow bothering you, Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the drunk) Why don't you go sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll sit here. Move over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drunk wants to sit beside Lilly, who looks to the waitress to solve the problem, but the waitress stands th with the coffee pot, looking helpless. The drunk bends to slide onto the seat. Lilly, exasperated, rabbit punches h in the throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drunk, astounded and in pain (and not breathing), staggers back, flailing, hitting the waitress's arm so th she slops coffee on him as his feet tangle and he falls heavily onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly, suddenly concerned, slides out of the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to one knee beside the drunk, who clutches his o throat with both hands, retching as he tries to inhale. L looks up at the astonished waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have hit him that hard. I guess I don't know my own strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drunk's friend arrives and helps Lilly get the drunk his feet. The drunk is breathing now, but shaken. He look Lilly with reproachful eyes. His friend transfers his annoyance at the drunk to Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matter of fact) I thought I did. You should take better care of your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbled) Outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drunk and his friend head for the exit, as Lilly turn the waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry a lady can't eat in here without being bothered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress is apologetic, and also in awe of Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't happen again, Ma'am, I promise. Dinner's on the house. More chili? Dessert? We have lovely pecan pie, my husband makes it himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds nice. Pecan pie. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly sits down as the waitress goes back behind the coun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on the waitress, as she puts down the coffee pot brings out the pecan pie, prepares to slice it, pauses, l with wonder toward Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The setting is a wide porch or lanai pretending to be a 1 century locale; a mix of western and antebellum south; th usual tourist confusion of histories. The effect is both romantic and false. Roy and Myra linger over wine, near t end of their meal. Roy's relaxed, happy, expansive. Myra' pleased but watchful, the bird watching the worm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were right, I had to get out of that hospital. Nothing wrong with me any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (purring) I'll sign that affidavit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great to get away, take it easy. Next week, I'll get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already went back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indulgent smile) I watched you. Working the tap on those soldier boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (elaborate innocence) Working the what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She mimes rolling the die, slowly, showing how it will ro out of her hand just so, then speaks to him as though to bright child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tap. What you do for a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a salesman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on the grift. Same as me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demonstrating patience) Myra, I'm not following this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demonstrating exasperation) Roy, you're a short-con operator. And a good one, I think. Don't talk to me like I'm another square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy leans back, studying her, thinking it over, makes up mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk the lingo. What's your pitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long end. Big con.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Nobody does that single-o.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was teamed ten years with the best in the business. Cole Langley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was beautiful. And getting better all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthusiasm building) It is, Roy! And now, right now, it's the perfect time, the best time since I've been in the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New skyscrapers are separated by blank fields or small ol buildings. Almost no traffic. A white limo drives alone d the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All over the southwest, you've got these businessmen, they were making money when everybody was making money, they think that means they're smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra, dressed expensively and fashionably, sits with GLOUCESTER HEBBING, a stocky businessman, sixtyish. Their manner suggests intimacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now they're hurting. Everything they had was because of oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glossy, but no people around. The limo stops, the mustach CHAUFFEUR hops out and holds the door as Myra and Hebbing emerge and cross to enter the building, Myra carrying an attache case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They still got money, but they need more money, and that's just the kind of guy Cole and me like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chauffeur gets back behind the wheel, adjusts the interior mirror so he can see himself, peels off his moustache, scratches his upper lip, refits the moustache to his liking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This building has a central atrium with corridors circlin it, waist-high walls on the atrium side, glass-walled elevators rising up through the atrium. Myra and Hebbing visible in an elevator coming up to a high floor. It stop and they exit, moving down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the oil money was good, they put up all these office buildings, and now they're half empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU, translucent glass in door with company name: COE, ST FELLOWES & ASSOCIATES, STOCK BROKERAGE - London - New Dallas - Los Angeles - Tokyo. CAMERA PANS to follow Myra Hebbing as they enter the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE showing the well-furnished outer office, the attractive and competent RECEPTIONIST welcoming Myra as someone she knows, gesturing her through, Myra graciously accepting, moving on. Hebbing's impressed by everything, trying not to show it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll give you anything to move in; first two months free, redecoration, whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE in a clerical office, four CLERKS at well-equipp desks with computer terminals, hard at work. Maps and clocks on the walls indicate the world. Myra and Hebbing pass through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They help you set up the store!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE in the PRIVATE SECRETARY'S office, she on the ph nodding and smiling at Myra and waving her through. Myra leads the way, opening a door marked HENRY FELLOWES, Part

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the roper, I go out and find them and bring them in. Cole ran the store, and he was the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra and Hebbing enter an office decorated with sleekly understated opulence; the view through large windows is o apparently-prosperous skyscrapers. Cole, a plausible rich businessman, happily greets Myra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Beth! As beautiful as ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts a dubious eyebrow toward Hebbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gentle disapproval) I see you brought a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mary Beth, Myra has a faint southern-belle accent and clinging flirtatiousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Hebbing is my bodyguard, my strong right arm. Gloucester Hebbing, may I present my fine stockbroker, Henry Fellowes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men shake hands, Hebbing open and pleased and dignifi Cole clearly holding something back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Myra; gentle warning)  Mary Beth, what we have here, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaily innocent) Oh, I told Mister Hebbing all about it, how brilliant you are at making money for your special clients!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Mary Beth, I hope you aren't spreading this good news too widely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, of course not! I know how dangerous this is. But I would trust Mister Hebbing with anything. (to Hebbing; suggestive) Wouldn't I, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Hebbing looks manly and flustered and pleased, Cole brings from under his desk a partially full gray canvas s marked Federal Reserve Bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll have to take your word for it, Mary Beth. Here's your money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocent avarice) Goody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra opens her attache case on the desk. Cole takes bande stacks of bills from the sack, packs them neatly in the c Hebbing tries not to look envious and impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEBBING'S POV: The top bill in each stack is a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREVIOUS SHOT. Myra takes a stack, riffles it for Hebbing benefit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that just beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra returns the stack to the case, talks to Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, next time, couldn't Mister Hebbing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) Mary Beth! This has never been anything but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know, I know, and you've been wonderful since I was widowed. But Mister Hebbing has-- (to Hebbing) -- you don't mind my telling him, darling -- (to Cole) -- suffered reverses. If he could...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gestures vaguely, unable to describe the situation accurately. Hebbing fills in, bluff and hearty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top up the tanks, as It were. Until this little glitch in the oil economy comes to an end. (man to man laugh) Not that I understand exactly what you do, not from Mary Beth's explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole broods, studying Hebbing, deciding at last to trust

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. If Mary Beth vouches for you, and if she told you the story already...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (girlish laugh) So here we are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemn) Mister Hebbing, we are talking about breaking the law here, I want to be sure you understand that. No one gets hurt, but the law does get broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a real sport; laughing) Well, that's what the law's for, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still serious) And I don't just mean the SEC. We could have the FBI breathing down our necks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly serious) I certainly hope not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loose talk is the one thing I worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can keep my mouth shut, Mister Fellowes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Describing the scheme, Cole becomes increasingly enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, then. Sit down, sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hebbing sits on the sofa, Myra beside him, holding his ar both of hers. Cole paces, describing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tokyo Exchange is nine hours ahead of us, New York one hour behind. There isn't one hour of the day when both are open. Information moves, but it has to wait. Now, we have a young fellow working here -- Do you know what a hacker is, Mister Hebbing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of those computer geniuses, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right! And this boy tapped into that main link between Tokyo and the New York Stock Exchange. He can give us, when it's really useful, a seven second delay in that movement of information. Do you know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hebbing doesn't want to admit ignorance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you've got your information ahead of New York, I see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every once in a while, a major change comes through. We have seven seconds to take advantage, put our buy order, our sell order, into the computer in New York before the Tokyo data comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to be ready. We have to have the money, and we have to know what the information means, and we have to move immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) Seven seconds. I don't see how you do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These machines -- They're in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole crosses to an inner door, pushes it partway open, lo back grinning with his hand on the knob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want a look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Henry, no, that's just boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bare dusty room. A ladder leans against a wall, a paint on the floor beside it. Only Cole is visible in the open doorway. He speaks back into the main office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come take a look. An entire-suite of main-frame computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not really interested, Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole remains in the doorway, luring Hebbing with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quite a sight. You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole's pushing this too far. Hebbing's thinking politenes requires him to look. Myra's nervous, her smile with an e to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, don't try Mister Hebbing's patience. He knows what machines look like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole smiles at the empty room again, looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you're sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole liked to take risks, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy and Myra at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't think they were risks. He was so good, Roy, he could just play with the mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when he got serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd explain he had to have cash, so there wouldn't be any paper trail for the SEC. And a lot of cash, or it wasn't worth while. The least we ever took was forty thousand, and the most was one hundred eighty-five thousand dollars! From one sucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought these people were broke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, Roy, just cash poor. They had savings accounts, stocks to sell, houses to mortgage. Sell their wife's jewelry. Oh, they had a lot of money, when they put their minds to it. Or when I put their minds to it. I stayed with them, that's the roper's job, made them get up every penny they could raise, turn it all over to Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a month later, the sucker calls the cops and you're on the run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no! He never calls the cops, not after we give him the blow-off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra puts a blood-filled four-inch-square plastic package into her bra on the left side, then puts on a white blous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three or four days after Cole got the money, he'd phone the sucker, tell him he'd made the move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra and Hebbing hurry across the sidewalk from the limo, each carrying an attache case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our buy was in the computer, we were rich, he should come collect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra and Hebbing enter, Cole meets them, all happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are! Two rich people!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must admit, Mister Fellowes, I had moments I was worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brought a case? Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole brings out the canvas sack from under the desk, reac in, brings out a stack of bills. The door opens and two m in suits and topcoats and hats enter, one of them flashin badge. (These are, altered, two of the clerks from before

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it right there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cool outrage) What? This is a private office!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FBI! Stock fraud, tampering with Exchange communications --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole suddenly loses all control, becomes a gibbering wrec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! No! The scandal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second man approaches Hebbing, pencil and notebook at ready, manner cold and tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My --? I don't I only --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams at Myra) You! You and your goddamn big mouth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified) Henry, no, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did you tell? Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one or two of the girls, just, they wouldn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole pulls a pistol from his desk drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Fellowes, that isn't going to do you any good. Put that down, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole ignores him, staring in frantic hatred at Myra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ruined me! You destroyed me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry, no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole shoots her, the SOUND very loud, the men flinching a Myra slaps her hand to her breast; blood spurts between h fingers. In terror, she turns toward Hebbing, who stares the blood seeping down her white blouse. She tries to spe can't. She reaches out, her bloody hand sliding down Hebbing's front without getting any purchase, leaving a s of blood diagonally across his jacket, shirt and tie. She topples forward. Hebbing tries to hold her, but she slips the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole runs around the desk toward the door, waving the gun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back! Get back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men warily move away from the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kill the first one that follows me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole runs from the room. The two men pull guns from hip holsters under their coat-tails. Hebbing, kneeling beside Myra, watches them approach the door, crouch, run through Hebbing rises, looks around, runs to the inner door, find locked. He crosses to the main door, looks out, cautiousl creeps from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hebbing hurries through the empty secretary's office and the other door. The two men enter from a different door a cross to re-enter Cole's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole stands behind a pillar, watching. Across the way, Hebbing comes out of the office, staring around, trying t wipe the blood from his clothes. In obvious panic, he run the elevator, presses the button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE through the glass wall into the elevator as it stops. The doors open, Hebbing hurries in, frantically ja the button. The elevator descends. CAMERA PANS to Cole co around the corridor, entering the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General hilarity. The secretary, two men, other two clerk chauffeur and receptionist are all present, opening champagne, Hebbing's money now out of the sack and spread the desk. Myra, stripped to the waist (unconcerned about others present) cleans blood from her breasts with damp towels. He and Myra look at one another across the room, broadly smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra's very up, from reliving this story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Roy, it was great! We were rolling in dough, lived wherever we wanted, only pulled two or three scams a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to Cole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly evasive) He retired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstate where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atascadero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where they keep the criminally insane, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra turns her face away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expensive room. Cole, naked, expression haunted and craze sits cross-legged on the bed. Myra enters, happy, carryin dress shop boxes. She stops, shocked, when she sees Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, baby. Not again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at the floor over the edge of the bed, like a shipwreck victim in a raft looking at the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hollow. You'll fall through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra drops the packages on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole, it'll be all right. Honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened but determined) Can't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just the strain again, the stress. We'll take a vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all hollow. Nothing behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She approaches him, scared but needing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole, you scare me when this happens. One of these times...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches him. He suddenly lashes out, knocking her backward, glaring at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Demon! Demon! That's why you can walk on it! Demon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartbroken) Oh, Cole, please. Please come out of it. What would I do without you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distracted, gone, unaware of her existence, he gazes arou hugs himself, sits staring at demons. She watches him, mournful, knowing he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra looks back at Roy. Her expression makes it clear she isn't going to tell him any more than she already has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He retired, and that's it. But I didn't. I'm still the best long-con roper you'll ever see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy laughs, genuinely pleased by her and also tacitly let his questions drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just bet you are, too. And now you're trying to rope me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing enthusiasm) Join up with you! I watched you, Roy, I've been watching you, wondering if I should talk about this at all, or maybe just... (shrug)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a hike, you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a partner, Roy. I need an inside man, and you're it. You could be as wonderful as Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dubious) I don't know, Myra, I never had partners. I never needed them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to take soldiers for a hundred bucks. But how about taking a bank president for a hundred grand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy doesn't like this; he's feeling pressured. Myra sees but believes she's got him anyway, so she can let up. She pats his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about it. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easy to promise) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little drunk and happy, Roy and Myra come down the corr together, then make it obvious they're going into separat rooms, across the corridor from one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coy, sexy) See you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy complains, but half-heartedly, half humorously; this argument has already taken place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't see why we have to have separate rooms. You expect your father to come through?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Separate bathrooms, darling. I will not lay out all my cosmetics for you to knock over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nevertheless grumpy) Things a man isn't supposed to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soothing) You don't mind, really, do you, Roy? It's been such a wonderful evening, I guess I just wore myself out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I'm pretty tired myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They unlock the opposing doors, look back at one another. Myra's smile and good-night wave are consciously cute. Ro response is a little forced. They go into their rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once he's alone, Roy stops trying to look like a good spo Disgusted, he tosses the room key onto the dresser, then crosses to sliding glass doors closed in front of a balco He's about to close the drapes when he looks out, changes mind, unlocks and opens the door. He steps outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high floor, with a wide view of ocean and starry sky. R leans on the rail, looking out, thinking. He mutters to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long con. I'm the one's been conned. Who needs this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues to stand there, taking some solace from the night. BEAT. Phone RINGS. Confused, irritated, he turns t look into the room. Phone RINGS. At last, he goes back in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy crosses to pick up the phone, grumpy and suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) Open your door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? (grins; gets it) What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) Open it and find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy hangs up and crosses to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE directly at the door as Roy opens it, showing My door open across the way, Myra standing in her doorway na She waves at him to move over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gangway!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy steps back, holding his door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE down the hall as Myra skips across from her room Roy's, her door slamming behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra runs in, giggling. Roy shuts the door, laughing at h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coquettish) I hope you don't mind, sir. I just washed my clothes, and I couldn't do a thing with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's pleased, but at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You -- I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sudden burst of laughter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could have seen your face when I told you good night! You looked so, so... Ah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clean anonymous Holiday Inn. Lilly, dressed for the tra sits at the round table under the swag light, sorting thr her business purse. There's a folded newspaper on the tab KNOCK on the door. She's startled. For just a second, she like a trapped animal. Then she's calm again. She turns t purse around, opens another zipper section, removes a pis and a silencer, quickly screws the silencer onto the pist lays the pistol on the table and covers it with the newspaper. Then she crosses to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE to include Roy in the doorway, grinning, easy. Lilly's surprised, pleased, but wary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy! What are you doing in San Diego?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering) Myra and me come down to LaJolla for the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly makes a face, but no comment, at Myra's name, as sh closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you come out to the track, don't know me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't hit the track. The beach. Couple a nice restaurants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes from his pockets the wads of money held removed the clown pictures, extends them toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four grand. For the hospital. Is that enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distressed) Roy, I don't want money from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pay my debts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (level skeptical look) You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since she won't take the money, he turns to put it on the table beside her purse, pushing the newspaper out of the revealing the gun. He gives it a surprised smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expecting visitors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That was the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to unscrew the silencer and put both pieces b in her purse. Roy, watching, points at the still angry bu on her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to put a bandage on that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No can do. Have to dip in and out of my bag too much. Besides, it'll heal in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disdainful and hurt, she pushes at the wads of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, take that back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His own hostility shows through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not used to being vulnerable, can neither hide it n really express it; can't use it as a tactic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought... I was hoping we could play it straight with one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess not. You'll be heading east from here, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dull) After the meet. Back to Baltimore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... nice to see you again, Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, too, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy finds this parting unsatisfactory, but has nothing to add. With a shrug, he leaves. Lilly looks after him, her expression becoming resentful, dully angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra sits in the back seat of a taxi parked across the st from the motel. The door to Lilly's room is visible in b. Roy walks toward the street from Lilly's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reaching the sidewalk, Roy turns to an empty cab parked o that side of the street, in front of the motel. Myra's dr shifts into gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Hold it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the guy we're following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy enters the other cab, which drives away, as Lilly com out of her room in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly gets into her Chrysler, backs away from the slot, drives to the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we follow her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on the two vehicles, as they leave the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the surf meets the turf. Over the punters' heads, o beyond the track, spreads the Pacific Ocean, unnoticed, ignored. In every shot in this sequence, the ocean is vis but not looked at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Lilly, with her heavy shoulderbag, moving alo empty tables, here and there picking up used tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Myra, on a different level, watching Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Lilly at the betting windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Myra, on a high vantage point in the stands. MAN near her watches the field through binoculars. Myra A if she can borrow them for a minute. Men are always happy do Myra favors; the man gives her the binoculars. She loo at the field briefly, then turns and looks through the binoculars the other way, outside the track. The man, surprised, looks the same way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN'S POV: The parking area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREVIOUS SHOT. The man looks in curiosity at Myra, who concentrates, adjusting the focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MYRA'S POV: Foreshortened through the binoculars, Lilly o the Chrysler's trunk, stashes money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREVIOUS SHOT. Myra smiles, turns it into a sweet thank-y smile as she returns the binoculars to their owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy dives into the pool, swims underwater to the ladder, climbs out near a YOUNG BLONDE on a chaise longue, who's admiring him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stay down real good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of my talents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing upward) Your mother's calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE to show Myra waving from her balcony, four fligh up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREVIOUS SHOT. Roy's at first surprised, then amused by t blonde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naughty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gathers up his towel and heads for the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy stands in heavy spray in the shower, half asleep, gen touching his stomach where the bruise used to be. KNOCK o door. He ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy! You drown in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rouses himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra moves away from the bathroom door. She's in a bad mo She paces back and forth, out onto the balcony, then back into the room as Roy comes out of the bathroom wearing a towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were gone for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casual) I went out to Delmar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly wary) ) The track? Did you run into Lilly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't see you, in other words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to make trouble, Roy. It's just, she's always so nasty to me, I thought, who is she to be so high and mighty. I saw her out there, and I called a friend of mine in Baltimore, so now I know who she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dry) You must have some very knowledgeable friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm well connected, Roy, Cole introduced me to a lot of people. Very valuable. Valuable for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Running your broker scam, you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthusiastic) You and me, Roy. What a team we'll make. We think alike; we get along together. Once or twice a year we take some slob, the rest of the time we live like this. You won't regret this, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regret what? I didn't say I was coming aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why not? I thought it was settled. What's holding you back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Myra, don't talk business here. This is time out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She considers him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, it would be too tough to give me a turndown here. Easier on home grounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrug) Yes or no. They're both easier at home. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra makes a visible effort to be accommodating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you say, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaggs sits at his computer terminal, bringing up data, no pleased by what he sees. Buzzer SOUNDS. He swivels to the desk, presses the intercom button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy Dillon, Mr. Kaggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! Send him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a now-we're-getting-somewhere manner, Kaggs turns ba to the VDT, punches up a different set of data, sits look at it in gloomy satisfaction. Roy enters, and Kaggs rises extending his hand across the desk. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to have you back, Roy. I was just looking at --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kaggs, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keen) You're turning me down? Makes no sense, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'm just not a leader of men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is, Mr. Kaggs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perk, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fine. Perk, the truth is, I like things the way they are now. Pick my own hours, have time for, uh, other activities...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well-rounded life. I respect that. But it has to have a center, Roy, something you care about, something you can think about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm just not ready for that yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deep sigh) Well, Roy, if that's the way you feel, I won't badger you. (forced laugh) Don't want to lose you as a salesman, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'd like to stay on. Just keep everything the way it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we'll do, then. But I tell you what, Roy. Before I hire anybody else, I'll ask you one last time. Fair enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's room. He has one of the clown pictures face down on coffee table. He takes money from his jacket pockets, cra it into the space, which is now just about full. As he's tightening the wing nuts closing the back, doorbell RINGS hurries, finishing the job, hanging the picture on the wa then crossing to open the door. Myra enters, ebullient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, guess what? I had to tell you right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him an enthusiastic kiss, then marches into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) And hello to you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called a fellow I know in Tulsa, the one who plays my chauffeur. There's a sucker there he says is made for us. And a boroker that just shut down, we can use their office, not change a thing! Now, I can scrape up ten grand without much trouble. That leaves fifteen or twenty for your end. We could start this weekend, get the sucker into position --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! When did this happen, that we're partners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last I looked, we were just talking things over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the setup's there. It's there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too good for the small-time, Roy. Move up to where there's big dough to be made, and you don't have to stick your neck out every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I like it where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra's need breaks through her good sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I don't! I had ten good years with Cole, and I want them back! I gotta have a partner! I looked and I looked and believe me, brother, I kissed a lot of fucking frogs, and you're my prince!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy tries to treat this lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I get any say in this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Because I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at her) That's what I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrown off course) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I say is, no. We don't do partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raging) For Christ's sake, why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mostly, because you scare the shit out of me. I've seen people like you before, baby. Double-tough and sharp as they come, and you get what you want or else. But you don't make it work forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No; history. Sooner or later, the lightning hits. I don't want to be around when it hits you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him, trying to find a chink in the armor, trying to find a reason, trying to find something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy the way I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By God, it's your mother. It's Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't get it) ) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure it is. That's why you act so funny around each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He frowns at her, not believing he understands her right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't act so goddamned innocent! You and your own mother, gah! You like to go back where you been, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a step toward her, rising toward fury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You watch that mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wise to you, I should have seen it before, you rotten son of a bitch. How is it, huh? How do you like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps her openhanded but hard, and she staggers back. pursues her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps her as hard with the other hand. Astonished, frightened, befuddled, she backpedals, bringing her forea up to protect her face. He grabs her two wrists in one ha holds them out of the way, slaps her forehand and backhan forehand and backhand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STOP!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly gets control of himself, releases her, steps into the middle of the room. He's angry, but also remorse sorry he lost control but still enraged at the enormity o her suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not like me. I don't do violence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cowers against the wall, peering in terror at him thr her raised arms. He settles down, becomes heavily calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why we wouldn't work together. You're disgusting. Your mind's so filthy, it's hard even to look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to the apartment door, pulls it open. Sunlight pours in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Myra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lowers her arms slowly, as though her whole body ache She's still scared, but angry now, too. She'd like to tel him off, but discretion tells her not to. She moves acros the room toward the open door, but stops, not wanting to that close to him. Understanding, he backs away from the doorway, gestures w cold irony for her to proceed. She moves to the threshold looks back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't even know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry again, Roy steps forward. She hastily steps outside and he slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra moves slowly along the balcony, muttering to herself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama. It's Mama. She's the one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops, holding the balcony rail, looking out at the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get yours, Mama. Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly's room; empty. Phone RINGS. Lilly enters, tired, wi her shoulderbag; the end of her work day. Phone RINGS. Sh frowns at it, expecting nothing good, then drops the shoulderbag on the bed, crosses, answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sudden smile doesn't entirely hide the wariness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy! An unexpected pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, troubled, paces while talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly, I've got a couple things to think about. Well, kind of job offers, kind of. Different ways to go. I'd kind of like to talk them out, you know? Maybe just hear myself talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly's delighted, but can't trust this moment more than other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sure, Roy. You want me to drive up --? Okay, fine, come on down. (kidding) It won't be a home-cooked meal, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kidding) Well, that's good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, but he's nervous, still uncertain, pacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? Who's a boy gonna talk to, if not his mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of the question makes him laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra's Cadillac eases to a stop across the street, where earlier waited in the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE through the windshield at Myra, settling down to wait, looking at the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly comes out of the bathroom, putting her lipstick awa a small purse. She's dressed carefully for tonight; upsca and respectable, without being stodgy. She crosses to the window -- night view outside -- and as she pulls the drap shut the phone RINGS. She looks at it in disappointment, crosses to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (expecting rejection) Roy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irv the accountant's office in Baltimore. He looks secret and scared, talks in a hush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly, listen, it's Irv. You were always decent with me, I'm taking a hell of a chance here. Somebody blew you out with Bobo. The car full of money. He's -- Lilly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty. The phone receiver dangles off the table on its co The door finishes closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly's Chrysler jounces out to the street, moving too fa making the turn, racing away. CAMERA PANS to Myra's Cadil pulling away from the curb, following. CAMERA HOLDS with two cars receding in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy drives down a San Diego street, is stopped by a red light, looks at his watch. He's late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty; as before. The door opens and the two thugs we saw earlier with Bobo enter, one putting a thick ring of keys away in his jacket pocket. They close the door, look arou the room. One goes to the closet, opens it, looks at the clothing inside, while the other goes into the bathroom. first crosses to the dresser, pulls open a drawer full of clothing. The second comes out of the bathroom. They look one another. The guy from the bathroom shakes his head. T other one points at the dangling phone, speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody spooked her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White Chrysler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy walks toward Lilly's room as the two thugs pass him, their way out. Roy knocks on Lilly's door, waits, knocks again. He tries to look through a crack in the drapes into the r then turns to look at the empty place where Lilly's Chrys had been. He shakes his head, knocks once more, looks at watch, turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted) Thanks a lot, Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly's white Chrysler pulls off the road into the front parking area of a new small motel. The car brakes to a st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE from the road as Myra's blue Cadillac drives slo by, while, in b.g., Lilly gets out of the Chrysler, movin though she's stiff and tired. Lilly enters the motel offi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CLERK, an elderly woman, turns away from a small TV s when Lilly enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening. Welcome to Phoenix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. I'd like a single for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, everything's the same size, same price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk extends a registration card and pen to Lilly, w takes them but doesn't yet start to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a very light sleeper, traffic noise keeps me wide awake all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sympathetic) Those trucks. I know exactly what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have something around back, facing away from the road?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk turns to consider the key rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll put you in one thirty-one. Very quiet. Faces the desert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds perfect. I can park my car back there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right in front of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to fill in the registration card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll want to leave an early wake-up call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem. My husband gets up the crack of dawn. (confidential) It's his kidneys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motel in b.g. The blue Cadillac, having turned around and come back, pulls off onto the shoulder of the road about fifty yards short of the motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over Myra's shoulder as she watches, through the windshie the Chrysler parked in front of the motel. Lilly comes ou the office over there, gets into the Chrysler, backs it u drives it out of sight past the motel. Myra puts the Cadi in gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clean anonymous motel room, with two beds. Lilly enters very weary, puts her shoulderbag on one of the beds, goes back outside and leaves the door open. She has backed the Chrysler into its spot just outside her room, so its trun visible through the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Lilly as she opens the rear door of the Chrys and leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly wrestles the rear seat out of position, reaches dow into the space under and behind it, and brings out a soft cloth overnight bag. It seems not too full but fairly hea She puts the bag on the ground outside the car and then pushes and prods the seat back into position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly shuts the car door, picks up the bag, and enters he room, shutting the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra enters. The clerk looks at her in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong? (embarrassed) I'm sorry. I thought you were the other lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly puts the bag on the bed with her shoulderbag. She o the overnight bag, takes from it a blond wig, a pair of h rim glasses and a passport. From her shoulderbag she take the pistol and silencer. She attaches the silencer to the pistol and puts the pistol under the pillow of the other

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra's checking in. She fills in the registration card wh the clerk considers her key rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you one oh seven. That's a very nice room, very handy, in the front, right by the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't you have something around back, where it's quieter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk sighs, looks at the key she'd taken from the ra reluctantly goes back to consider the situation again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody wants the back tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess everybody wants privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly, in nightgown, yawning, comes out of the bathroom, switching off its light. The shoulderbag and overnight ba and overnight bag's contents are still on one bed. Lilly into the other, switches off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virtually identical to Room 131. Myra enters, lugging a suitcase, and shuts the door behind herself. She puts the suitcase on one of the beds, opens it, paws through it, a brings out slippers, nightgown and robe. Briskly, she str and puts on the nightgown, the slippers and the robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back into the suitcase, she brings out a small snubnose pistol which she puts in the pocket of her robe. Next out the suitcase is a large ring of keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting on the other bed, she compares her room key with on the ring, takes three keys from the ring, and puts the her robe pocket along with the room key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting to her feet, she crosses to the dresser, picks up ice bucket, and leaves the room, closing the door behind herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, the door, with its number. CAMERA PANS to pick up Myr approaching. She stops at room 132, looks at the Chrysler smiles at it in proprietary fashion, and pats the Chrysle the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she turns to the room. She takes the keys from her pocket, looks around to be sure she's alone, and bends ov the lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In very dim light, Myra enters the room, closes the door, moves toward the beds. CAMERA PANS with her. Keeping her on the sleeping form of Lilly, she puts the empty ice buc on the empty bed, then moves closer to Lilly. CAMERA PANS moving forward as Myra's arms move forward, moving to CU Lilly as Myra's hands (remaining IN FRAME) move forward a down. Her hands abruptly clamp on Lilly's throat. QUICK C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING SHOT. A plane lands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, looking stunned, is among the deplaning passengers spreading out across the terminal. He's met by PIERSON, a plainclothes detective, and a uniformed COP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy Dillon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Pierson, Phoenix police. I have a car here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The uniformed cop drives. Pierson and Roy sit in back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realize this is a shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, mostly, I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's natural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I mean, I don't believe it. Lilly is not a suicide. I know my mother, nothing would make her check out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, it was her all right. Her gun, even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I grant you, it's a little odd, shoot yourself with a gun with a silencer on it, but it was hers, all right. It really is your mother, Mister Dillon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may be Lilly, but it isn't suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested) Do you have any particular reason to say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother... Well, I guess it doesn't matter now. She worked for gamblers. She always knew they might turn on her some day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtful) A hit, you mean. Honestly, it doesn't have that feel to it, but I'll certainly consider the possibility. Thank you for telling me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that it matters. (looks out) This is the morgue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You up to it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Let's get it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing I have to caution you about. A gunshot wound...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) Yes, I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctant) Well, uh, you know, she ate the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not understanding) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, that's an unfortunate phrase, it slipped out, I'm, to tell you the truth, Mr. Dillon, this isn't an everyday occurrence around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low; getting it) Ate the gun. Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone who knows her well could still identify her, that's not the problem. It's just there's, uh, it's likely to be a shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening the door) Well, let's get the shock over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bare bright room with tiled walls, a few plastic chairs ordinary office door on one side and wide hospital swingi doors on the other. Pierson and Roy stand watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not many laughs in this room, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not many.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The swinging doors open and an ATTENDANT wheels in a gurn containing a body covered by a sheet. Roy braces himself. attendant pulls the sheet away from the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the attendant) Remove that. We'll want a full, uh, identification.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attendant removes the sheet. The body wears a nightgo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Roy, swallowing bile, as he forces himself to move forward and look down at the face. He immediately lo away again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No question, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, its -- Why did she--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He forces himself to look at the body again, his own face full of the unanswerable question. He looks her up and do then his eyes stop. He focuses on something, a look of surprise coming into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's POV: CU, the body's hands, crossed over the stomach the wrists crossed, the palms down, the clear backs of bo hands visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, Roy. He knows. Sharpness comes back into his expressi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's that, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to grin) Oh, yeah. That's that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT, Roy and Pierson. Pierson wants to leave, but Ro stands over the gurney. He chuckles. Pierson looks at him surprised and appalled. Roy ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing quietly) Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE. Myra's baby blue Cadillac drives, at extreme hig speed, alone on the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra's Cadillac drives slowly past, comes to a stop at th curb half a block away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE through the windshield at the driver, a woman, deeply weary. Her forearms are crossed on top of the stee wheel, her brow resting on the forearms. The burn on the of her right hand is visible in illumination from a nearb streetlight. Traffic goes by. BEAT. Lilly lifts her head, looking out at the night. She's very tired, but determine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE beside Lilly, inside the car. From the seat besi her she picks up Myra's large dangly earrings and fixes t in place. Then she puts on Myra's big-lensed dark sunglas (She's wearing the clothes Myra wore when checking into t motel.) Lilly checks her appearance in the rearview mirro then gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Simms at the desk, talking to a TELEPHONE REPAIRMAN steadily at work fixing the switchboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last modern thing I liked was the miniskirt. Your technology, now, nobody understands it, and that's the simple fact of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly enters in b.g., crosses to the elevator, presses th button. Simms waves to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) ) Evening, Mizz Langley!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator door opens, Lilly boards and presses the but The elevator door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New things come in here all the time, how do they work? You can ask your Ph.Ds, your highly educated, intelligent, professional people, you can say to them, how does that work, and you know what they'll tell you? You plug it in. And that's the way the donut dunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The balcony leading to Roy's apartment. It's illuminated light next to the public door from the interior hall. AN ANGLE on that door as Lilly cautiously opens it, looks and around while remaining mostly behind the door, then focuses on the light. She reaches out and unscrews the bu GO TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's place. Dark. SOUNDS of lock being picked. The door opens, showing only blackness outside, Lilly enters and s the door, then switches on the main light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah ANGLE on Lilly, in the middle of the room, distractedl biting her thumbnail as she looks around, calculating. Sh looks directly at something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly's POV: One of the box-framed pictures hanging on th wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREVIOUS SHOT. Lilly, making up her mind, crosses to the picture and takes it off the wall. She finds it surprisin heavy. She carries it to the coffee table, puts it down t on its back, sits on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE on Lilly studying the picture. She raps her knuc against the sides, looks to see if the front or sides ope someway, and finally turns the picture over, laying it fa down on the coffee table. She sees how to remove the back lifts it off, and looks at the stacks of money lying in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, Lilly, almost fainting with relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT. Lilly looks at the other picture, looks again the money, comes to a conclusion. She rises and leaves th room, deeper into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly switches on the light as she enters the room. She l around, crosses to the closet, goes through the stuff in there, finds an old attache case on the shelf. She brings out, puts it on the bed, opens it. Inside are a few decks cards and a paperback book. She tosses them onto the bed, checks the case, finds that one of the clasps works but t other doesn't. One is good enough. She carries the attach case out of the room, leaving the light on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly enters, puts the case on the coffee table beside th picture, scoops the money out of the picture and puts it the case. Then she unceremoniously dumps the picture on t floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly takes the second picture from the wall, puts it fac down on the coffee table, opens the back, transfers the m to the case. She closes the case, attaches the one clasp works, picks up the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Lilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SHOT, as Lilly whirls around, terrified and then relieved. Roy stands in the open apartment doorway, black behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Roy! You scared me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy enters the room and shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere else, that's for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just came back from Phoenix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious) Oh, yeah? Is the frame holding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks very solid, Lilly. Sit down. Take a minute, tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've really got to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dead, Lilly, it worked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for long. Not when they do a fingerprint check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should they? The cops are satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo won't be. He'll spend the money to make sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even so. You still got time. Relax a minute, tell me what happened. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures at the sofa. Lilly's holding the attache case The gutted pictures are lying around, one on the coffee t and one on the floor. She looks around at everything, awk and embarrassed. But Roy hasn't said anything. And he's between her and the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She backs up, sits on the sofa, puts the case on her lap. pulls a chair over so it's directly between Lilly and the door. He sits, looking at her with polite interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra followed you, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must have been the one that blew me off with Bobo. I guess to get me running. Did you tell her about my stash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (isn't worth discussing) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you wouldn't. That's what she was after, though. But why hit on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't go in on a deal with her. She blamed you for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a shaky laugh) As though you do what I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold grin) That's pretty funny, all right. What happened in Phoenix?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remembered emotion makes Lilly talk in little fast cluste of words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, it was terrible. You read about people killing people and all that, but when it happens, my God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myra, in nightgown, carrying the ice bucket, approaches R 131.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was in her nightgown, you know, the old grifter's dodge, nightgown and the Ice bucket and she just got into the wrong room by mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU, Lilly asleep. Very dim light. The shadows shift on he face as Myra OUT OF FRAME approaches. Myra's hands ENTER FRAME, abruptly clamp on Lilly's throat. Lilly's eyes pop open wide, staring, her mouth stretches open. Myra's arms locked straight, pressing her weight down onto her hands squeezing Lilly's throat. Lilly clutches at Myra's finger tries to reach Myra's face, twists and squirms, then sudd lifts her arm up and behind her head, hand dipping under pillow, coming out with the silenced gun, pushing the gun upward, straight-arm, the gun moving up OUT OF FRAME. SOU of shot. Blood sprays Lilly's face. Myra's body drops dow onto her, at an angle, so we can still see Lilly's horrif face over Myra's shoulder as Lilly gasps for breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly stares across the room, breathing hard, reliving th experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sat in there with her, I thought, what do I do now? Run and I've got Bobo and the law after me. Stay, and how do I explain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way's perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly sits back, showing that relief again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is, isn't it? And maybe it's a break for me after all. I've been wanting out of the racket for years, and now I'm out. I can make a clean start, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've already made a start. Doesn't look that clean, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the awkwardness. Lilly looks guilty and embarrasse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I hated to take your money, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be sorry. You're not taking it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly reacts as though he's slapped her. But then she get her determination back. She splays out both hands, palm d on the attache case on her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need this, Roy. I can't run without money, and if I can't run I'm dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a few bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Myra's stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scornful) Her credit cards. How far am I gonna get with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far enough. Maybe up to San Francisco. Or St. Louis, someplace new. Start over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're smart, Lilly, and you're good-looking. You won't have any trouble finding a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appalled) A job? I've never had a legit job in my life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're gonna start, if you hope to live through this. A square job and a quiet life. You start showing up at the track or the hot spots and Bobo's boys will be all over you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Roy, I know what to do with myself! It's a big world out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not any more. Lilly, listen, I'm giving you good advice. I'm following it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't get it) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it over, and you were right. You wanted me out of the rackets, and now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bedeviled, aggravated) Roy, that's fine, but I don't have time for this. Bobo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd be happy for me. After all, you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo isn't after you! Bobo's after me, and he's goddamn good! But so am I. I'm a survivor, Roy. I survive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you do, so that's why --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to survive, my way, I need money. Bobo knows about the stash in the car, so I didn't dare touch it, not if Lilly Dillon's dead. So that leaves this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lilly sits back again, brooding at Roy, trying to think h to get to him, how to get through him or around him. She sighs, licks her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. You probably shouldn't either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I'm goddamn thirsty. Ice water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, that sounds nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
